title: Brexit nears deal, opioid trial begins, Canadians head to the polls: 5 things you need to know Monday
text:
Britain's Parliament could vote on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal

Britain's Parliament could vote as early as Monday on a deal negotiated by Prime Minister Boris Johnson with the European Union for an orderly departure from the bloc. Parliament was expected to vote on the deal Saturday, but instead passed a last-minute motion to postpone an important Brexit vote, legally forcing Johnson to request a delay on the U.K.’s exit. The outcome injects new confusion and uncertainty into the Brexit process and piles pressure on Britain's leader just three months into his tenure. His government argued that any delay increases the likelihood of a "no deal" Brexit, which experts warn could harm Britain’s economy and lead to border chaos.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson arrives for a media conference at an EU summit in Brussels, on Oct. 17, 2019. (Photo: Frank Augstein, AP)

Canada's election to test Justin Trudeau's tenure

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is locked in a dead heat as his country heads to the polls Monday. Trudeau’s Liberal Party and the Conservative Party, led by his top rival, Andrew Scheer, are in a neck-and-neck race, recent polls show.While Trudeau’s government has passed some popular legislation such as the legalization of cannabis, the administration has been plagued by several controversies and scandals. Several photos of Trudeau wearing blackface when he was younger surfaced in September, but political analyst P.J. Fournier, who runs the poll tracking website 338Canada, said the scandal had little effect on public opinion. Should the Conservatives win more parliamentary seats, Fournier pointed out there is still a chance Trudeau could stay in power by forming a coalition with the New Democratic Party.

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau apologizes again for 'brownface' at campaign event (Photo: AP)

Sweeping opioid trial scheduled to begin after settlement rejection

The first federal trial related to the nation's opioid epidemic is scheduled to start Monday in Cleveland after settlement talks failed. Two Ohio counties claim that six drug companies that made prescription painkillers engaged in a deadly conspiracy that has harmed their communities and generated huge public costs. An offer of $48 billion in cash, treatment drugs and services was rejected as lawyers for the 2,400 cities and counties involved clashed with states attorneys general over the distribution of the settlement. The trial has been considered a test case for similar lawsuits from governments across the country and possibly the linchpin for a settlement of the more than 2,300 suits filed against drug companies.

Don't miss the Orionid meteor shower late Monday

Keep your eyes to the night sky late Monday night and especially early Tuesday morning – you might get a peek at the Orionid meteor shower. The Orionids are some of the fastest and brightest among meteor showers because the Earth is hitting the stream of particles almost head-on. How fast? Most zip by at 41 miles per second, which translates to about 148,000 mph. The best time to view the shower is after midnight, when the constellation Orion rises high above the horizon. Try to avoid light pollution and don't use binoculars or telescopes. If you miss this shower, you can still catch the Leonids in November and the Geminds in December.

'Maleficent: Mistress of Evil' finishes off 'Joker's run at No. 1 – but not by much

Disney's "Maleficent: Mistress of Evil" has knocked "Joker" out of the No. 1 spot at the box office, but just barely, with final numbers expected Monday. Studios on Sunday estimated that the film starring Angelina Jolie grossed $36 million in North America and $117 million internationally in its first weekend in theaters. The first film had a much stronger domestic showing, opening to nearly $70 million in 2014. "Joker" landed in second place in its third weekend with $29.2 million. The villain origin story has grossed more than $247 million domestically. Third place went to another sequel, "Zombieland: Double Tap," with $26.7 million.
